comment.author: 79003659@N03
comment._content: Commented on at dl.dropbox.com/u/5737284/gordon-ck.htm re the different sizes of the two rivers each side of the interfluve along which the highway from the City to Hornsby runs.

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: Um, sorry! - this aint Roseville (or Rosevile) Bridge on Middle Harbour. Gotta love Series 4481 ! It is Fig Tree Bridge on the Lane Cove River. Built 1885 and since replaced by the current bridge (1963) - en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fig_Tree_Bridge . Hunters Hill in the background.

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: See this colourised postcard - [http://www.flickr.com/photos/patopostcards/2213469523/] And a great collection of 7 other postcards - www.flickr.com/search/?w=22468896@N05&q=fig%20tree%20...

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: Wonderful description of a ferry ride from Darling Harbour to the delights of Fig Tree and the Lane Cove River - ATCJ - Saturday 27/07/1889 p.28 (illustrations p.26) - trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/71121619/5435014

comment.author: 74004041@N06
comment._content: Rosevile in Roseville bridge is spelt incorrectly "I think".

comment.author: 27331537@N06
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] Yes! Looks like you are right! I shall update the caption!
Thanks for keeping us on our toes!

comment.author: 35179849@N08
comment._content: Well that definitely isn't the old Roseville Bridge.  Figtree Bridge, it is.   Old Roseville Bridge had an unusual slope on it.

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: c. 1868 - investigator.records.nsw.gov.au/asp/photosearch/photo.asp... This is the same image as identified by the NGA as being byJohn Degotardi (Senior) in 1869-70 - artsearch.nga.gov.au/Detail.cfm?IRN=127832
